COWAN All-American Joe Cowan starts to scoop up loose ball while two Maryland defensemen prepare to clobber the Jay attackman. Joe scored three goals and two
assists, giving him a tie with Billy Morrill for the all-time Hopkins scoring crown in one

season.

M cCAIITY Downy McCarty maneuvers in front of Maryland's goal before scoring
one of his four unassisted shots. Downy had five goals and one assist on the day,
against Terp net minder, Norm Vander Schuyt. The News-Letter deemed him the most
valuable player of the title contest.

By JASON ICRAVITT

Dennis A. Estis

Lacrosse Manager

Blue Jay's 9th goal serves to illustrate Downy's will
to win. With the ball on the ground in front of the
crease, it is the defender's job either to knock his
opponent on the ground or "take his arms off' —
the point is that things get awfully rough. McCarty,
however, ignored his defender's efforts and maintained the poise necessary to bat the ball into the
goal before getting decked himself. Several moments
later he came back for his fifth score of the day.
Yet great lacrosse players are more than talented
athletes. McCarty is president of the H-club and
head of ROTC this year: next season will find the
handsome senior in the air-defense. Perhaps more
importantly, however, McCarty is a team player.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 21, 1968

PAGE 3

NEWS-LETTER

Hop Clinches Win in Last Period
Jay's

Victory Marks First Undisputed
Lax Championship Since '57

Nest

By RICH HOLLANDER
Sports Editor

They are the best there is at what they do. The superlative connotes the Blue Jays of Johns Hopkins University and what they do
better than anyone else is play lacrosse.
Saturday was the 49th reunion of a stick rivalry with the University that dates back to 1895. On the initial meeting the Jays shutout
Maryland by 10 goals. In 68' Hopkins equaled 95's offense but yielded 8 to the tenacious visitors. So for the first time in eleven campaigns the Hop has sole possession of the National Championship.
It is true that Saturday's contest held neither the pageantry of the
Rose Bowl nor the glamour of the NCAA basketball finals, but in
nostalgic eyes of all those elderly yet dignified alumni the game had
all the appeal of youth itself.
Above and Beyond ...
The most outstanding aspect of the afternoon took place before
the first face off. A mammouth crowd suffered through interminable
lines in order to enter the stadium and once inside felt the agony of
two endless hours of waiting. The wait was not Unrewarded. Besides
witnessing a superbly coordinated logistical effort by the security
guards, (that would have made our boys in Saigon proud); they saw
"Testudo", the world's only terrapin powered by a Volkswagon engine, parade to jeers along the Hopkins side of the cinder track.
The wait was not in vain. The fans and a plethora of national reporters were treated to a blistering battle from two well conditioned
and coached teams. Maryland's plan was to stifle the Jay's potent attack through ball control, as they did a year ago at College Park.
Terp head coach John Howard pinned tough defenseman Jack Daily
against, number 25, JHU's incomparable Joe Cowan. Daily's success
was none greater than the previous ten who played Cowan this season. Joe ripped the nets 3 times and added 2 assists, placing himself
in a tie with Billy' Morrill's school record of 75 points in a season.
Could Have Been More
The understatement is that the game was tense throughout. Neither side was able to consistently captialize on the other's failures,
and gain the genre of momentum. Hopkins did manage to pressure
Maryland's goal by shooting salvos at goalie Norm Vander Schuyt
for a substantial portion of the afternoon. He adroitly speared 24.
Against a good goalie Hopkirs would have scored twenty,but Vander
Schuyt is great. Although this was the first complete game that Vanhis
der Schuyt has found himself on the short end of the score in
remagnificent
of
display
a
with
crowd
college career, he awed the
control.
flexes and body
The second quarter, when Maryland outscored Hopkins 3 to 2 was
particularly frustrating. Momentary lapses were converted by Maryland into goals. From my vantage point on the sideline, an emotional Bob Scott kept calling for Jesus Christ, yet he never put him on
the field. Scott didn't have to. Downy McCarthy had his finest hour
collecting 5 tallies and 1 assist. Not even the resurrection of 1966
All-American and footballer Alan Pastrana could restrain McCarty.
One does not have to be especially perceptive to concur with our selection of McCarty for most valuable player of the game honors.
The Thrill Of Victory
In many respects it's an absurdity to attempt to eulogize a team
that played 600 minutes of varsity lacrosse and whose record remains
as unblemished as the first day of practice. The perfection of the
Hopkins lacrosse team speaks for itself in the record and on the
field. Literary verbosity is a tool of rationalization, and this team
needs none. Forgive the contrivance of the superlative, but the 1968
edition of the Blue Jay stickmen is the "bestest." Enough said.

Sports Dook Picks
N-L "Dream Team"
By MARSHALL PAUL
Sports Editor, 1965-66

Picking an all star team is as
hard as deciding if Bobby Jones
was better than Jack Nicklaus,
Man O'War better than Native
Dancer, or Jimmy Lewis better
than Joe Cowan.
Nonetheless, since this is my
last article for the News-Letter, I
would like to pick the so-called
"dream team" from the four
squads that this year's senior class
has seen take the field for Coach
Bob Scott.
Starting with defense, I would
have to put two-time Schmeisscr
Award winner Hank Kaestner on
this team. It's hard to forget games
like the 1965 Hopkins-Maryland
clash, when Kaestner frustrated
the highly touted Jack Heim as
Hopkins rolled up a victory.
I would also have to include
Mike Clark and Mike Oidick on
this all star defense.

It's hard to pick the most outstanding midfield trio, especially
since Hopkins had more outstanding faces this season than usual.
However, my top choices would
be Jerry Schnydman, Charlie
Goodell and Lucky Mallonee. You
might also mention names like
Better and Szoka, but I don't
think they rate with these three.
Attack might be the hardest
unit to pick. Joe Cowan gets a
spot hands down. Downy McCarty, on the basis of his performance
this year, gets a position, too.
Phil Kneip has done a fine job on
the crease and has a shot at AllAmerica honors; but if we're picking .the three best overall attackment,our third spot would have to
go to Jerry Pfeiffer.
Finally, as goalie for this 196568 "dream team," John Dashiells,
who graduated with Pfeiffer in
1965, has to get my vote, despite
the fine play of Geof Berlin over
the past three-years.

By MIKE PHILLIPS
Senior attackman Downy McCarty made his last Homewood
stick appearance his most outstanding Saturday, as his five goals
and one assist led the Hopkins lacrosse team to a 10-8 conquest of
previously-unbeaten Maryland,
thus clinching the school's first
undisputed collegiate championship since 1957.
The score was tied 8-8 midway
through the fourth period of that
topsy-turvy contest, witnessed by
as estimated 11,000 fans, when
McCarty's final two scores provided the Jay victory margin. The
6-1 senior put home a loose ball
from the side of the crease following a Phil Buck shot on extra-man
at 6:35 of the period, and came
from behind about two minutes
later for his fourth unassisted
score of the day.
Early Lead
McCarty's first two scores, both
unassisted, sparked Hopkins to a
2-0 lead by 6:00 of the second
quarter; in the early going the
Jays, with fine midfield play,
thoroughly dominated the action
and were only deterred from a bigger lead by the (to put it mildly)
outstanding work of Terp goalie
Norm Vander Schuyt. Hopkins had
an extra-man advantage at least
four times in the first period, and

Maryland got no more than five
shots in the opening fifteen minutes.
However, the College Park contingent staged the first of many
rallies from there, and knotted the
count at 3-3 by halftime. Middie
Steve Pfeiffer fed crease attackman Fred Graham for a fifteen
foot straightaway shot on extraman a minute after McCarty's
second goal, while Joe Cowan
made it 3-1 by coming from behind and putting an over-the-shoulder shot past Vander Schuyt at
8:00 of the period. Then Maryland midfielder Reed Kaestner(on
a high bounce shot) and attackman Doug Carter(on another feed
from Pfeiffer) tallied before the
half to induce the tie.
LaVaute Scores
Terp attackman Steve LaVaute
put his team ahead 4-3 three minutes into the second half, before
Hopkins ripped off three scores inside of a minute to move ahead
6-4. Cowan(on a feed from McCarty) scored from about ten feet to
the front and right of the goal on
extra-man at 5:50; tallied on a
similar play from the left after
Phil Kneip's assist thirty seconds
later; and fed McCarty in front of
the goal after the ensuing faceoff.
But Maryland came back again.
La Vaute and Kaestner scored
unassisted at 9:35 and 10:20 of

the period, before Jim Feely's ten
foot left-hander following Cowan's
feed from behind made it temporarily 7-6 a minute later. Then,
with a minute left in the quarter,
Pfeiffer and Graham teamed up for
an extra-man play like that which
scored in the second period, as the
Maryland crease attackman drilled
a low bouncer past Hopkins goalie
Geoff Berlin to make the score 7-7
after three periods.
Final Quarter Action
LaVaute put the Terps ahead
for the last time twenty-five seconds into the final period, when
he apparently surprised Berlin
with a medium-range, right-handed, on-the-run bounce shot; but
Buck fed Charlie Goodell thirty
seconds later to again knot the
count. From there, the action
went back and forth for about
eight minutes, setting the stage
for McCarty's late heroics.
As inferred above, the play of
the Hopkins midfields, matched
against Maryland units generally
rated the country's best, was a
major factor in the win. The Jays
were outdone 63-56 as a team on
ground balls; but, paced by soph
Doug Honig and senior Bob Carter, took fifteen of twenty-four
faceoffs, and outshot the Terps
62-31.The quality of performance
of the second (Carter, Wes Bachur,
and Bill Scroggs) and third (Feely,
Steve Latson, and Russ Moore)
midfields dropped little from that
of the first, where injured soph
Andy Fisher did a capable fill-in
for hobbled regular Charlie Coker.
Cowan Ties Record '
For all the fuss over teammate
McCarty, Cowan's customary pow
ers hardly declined against Maryland, as the 5-10 junior solidified
his claim to a second straight first
team All-America bid by recording three goals and two assists and
thus (with thirty scores and 45 assists) tieing the school socrirrg record of 75 points set by Billy Morrill in 1959. McCarty finished the
year with 51 points (31 and 20)
and crease attackman Kneip with
32(27 and 5).
All in all, in this writer's opinion, the 10-8 final margin for the
Maryland game was a bit deceptive, as Hopkins superiorities were
manifest in many areas.The abouteven midfield play aside, the
Homewood squad showed a marked advantage at both ends of the
field: the Jays bombarded Vander
Schuyt with 62 shots to the 31
Maryland sent at Berlin; few, if.
any, Terp scores were the result
of an attackman clearly beating
the close defense of Mike Clark,
John Cardillo, Paul Weiss, and
Joe Carlton; while Cowan and
McCarty often shook Maryland defenders Jack Dailey and Hugh
Mallon, and were only prevented
from scoring more prolifically by
Vander Schuyt's heroics. In fact,
if anything kept Maryland in the
game,especially in the early going,
it was the work of the 5-10 junior
Terp netminder, at least ten of
whose 24 saves were a spectacular
variety.
Saturday's game marked the final appearance for seniors McCarty Kneip, Bachur, Carter, Berlin,
Joe Carlton (who performed very
well — as a substitute close defenseman in the fourth quarter),
Doug Tribull, and Ted Leach.

COWAN All-American Joe Cowan starts to scoop up loose ball while two Maryland defensemen prepare to clobber the Jay attackman. Joe scored three goals and two
assists, giving him a tie with Billy Morrill for the all-time Hopkins scoring crown in one

season.

M cCAIITY Downy McCarty maneuvers in front of Maryland's goal before scoring
one of his four unassisted shots. Downy had five goals and one assist on the day,
against Terp net minder, Norm Vander Schuyt. The News-Letter deemed him the most
valuable player of the title contest.

Lacrosse Manager

Blue Jay's 9th goal serves to illustrate Downy's will
to win. With the ball on the ground in front of the
crease, it is the defender's job either to knock his
opponent on the ground or "take his arms off' —
the point is that things get awfully rough. McCarty,
however, ignored his defender's efforts and maintained the poise necessary to bat the ball into the
goal before getting decked himself. Several moments
later he came back for his fifth score of the day.
Yet great lacrosse players are more than talented
athletes. McCarty is president of the H-club and
head of ROTC this year: next season will find the
handsome senior in the air-defense. Perhaps more
importantly, however, McCarty is a team player.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 21, 1968

PAGE 3

NEWS-LETTER

Hop Clinches Win in Last Period
Jay's

Victory Marks First Undisputed
Lax Championship Since '57

Nest

By RICH HOLLANDER
Sports Editor

They are the best there is at what they do. The superlative connotes the Blue Jays of Johns Hopkins University and what they do
better than anyone else is play lacrosse.
Saturday was the 49th reunion of a stick rivalry with the University that dates back to 1895. On the initial meeting the Jays shutout
Maryland by 10 goals. In 68' Hopkins equaled 95's offense but yielded 8 to the tenacious visitors. So for the first time in eleven campaigns the Hop has sole possession of the National Championship.
It is true that Saturday's contest held neither the pageantry of the
Rose Bowl nor the glamour of the NCAA basketball finals, but in
nostalgic eyes of all those elderly yet dignified alumni the game had
all the appeal of youth itself.
Above and Beyond ...
The most outstanding aspect of the afternoon took place before
the first face off. A mammouth crowd suffered through interminable
lines in order to enter the stadium and once inside felt the agony of
two endless hours of waiting. The wait was not Unrewarded. Besides
witnessing a superbly coordinated logistical effort by the security
guards, (that would have made our boys in Saigon proud); they saw
"Testudo", the world's only terrapin powered by a Volkswagon engine, parade to jeers along the Hopkins side of the cinder track.
The wait was not in vain. The fans and a plethora of national reporters were treated to a blistering battle from two well conditioned
and coached teams. Maryland's plan was to stifle the Jay's potent attack through ball control, as they did a year ago at College Park.
Terp head coach John Howard pinned tough defenseman Jack Daily
against, number 25, JHU's incomparable Joe Cowan. Daily's success
was none greater than the previous ten who played Cowan this season. Joe ripped the nets 3 times and added 2 assists, placing himself
in a tie with Billy' Morrill's school record of 75 points in a season.
Could Have Been More
The understatement is that the game was tense throughout. Neither side was able to consistently captialize on the other's failures,
and gain the genre of momentum. Hopkins did manage to pressure
Maryland's goal by shooting salvos at goalie Norm Vander Schuyt
for a substantial portion of the afternoon. He adroitly speared 24.
Against a good goalie Hopkirs would have scored twenty,but Vander
Schuyt is great. Although this was the first complete game that Vanhis
der Schuyt has found himself on the short end of the score in
remagnificent
of
display
a
with
crowd
college career, he awed the
control.
flexes and body
The second quarter, when Maryland outscored Hopkins 3 to 2 was
particularly frustrating. Momentary lapses were converted by Maryland into goals. From my vantage point on the sideline, an emotional Bob Scott kept calling for Jesus Christ, yet he never put him on
the field. Scott didn't have to. Downy McCarthy had his finest hour
collecting 5 tallies and 1 assist. Not even the resurrection of 1966
All-American and footballer Alan Pastrana could restrain McCarty.
One does not have to be especially perceptive to concur with our selection of McCarty for most valuable player of the game honors.
The Thrill Of Victory
In many respects it's an absurdity to attempt to eulogize a team
that played 600 minutes of varsity lacrosse and whose record remains
as unblemished as the first day of practice. The perfection of the
Hopkins lacrosse team speaks for itself in the record and on the
field. Literary verbosity is a tool of rationalization, and this team
needs none. Forgive the contrivance of the superlative, but the 1968
edition of the Blue Jay stickmen is the "bestest." Enough said.

Sports Dook Picks
N-L "Dream Team"
By MARSHALL PAUL
Sports Editor, 1965-66

Picking an all star team is as
hard as deciding if Bobby Jones
was better than Jack Nicklaus,
Man O'War better than Native
Dancer, or Jimmy Lewis better
than Joe Cowan.
Nonetheless, since this is my
last article for the News-Letter, I
would like to pick the so-called
"dream team" from the four
squads that this year's senior class
has seen take the field for Coach
Bob Scott.
Starting with defense, I would
have to put two-time Schmeisscr
Award winner Hank Kaestner on
this team. It's hard to forget games
like the 1965 Hopkins-Maryland
clash, when Kaestner frustrated
the highly touted Jack Heim as
Hopkins rolled up a victory.
I would also have to include
Mike Clark and Mike Oidick on
this all star defense.

It's hard to pick the most outstanding midfield trio, especially
since Hopkins had more outstanding faces this season than usual.
However, my top choices would
be Jerry Schnydman, Charlie
Goodell and Lucky Mallonee. You
might also mention names like
Better and Szoka, but I don't
think they rate with these three.
Attack might be the hardest
unit to pick. Joe Cowan gets a
spot hands down. Downy McCarty, on the basis of his performance
this year, gets a position, too.
Phil Kneip has done a fine job on
the crease and has a shot at AllAmerica honors; but if we're picking .the three best overall attackment,our third spot would have to
go to Jerry Pfeiffer.
Finally, as goalie for this 196568 "dream team," John Dashiells,
who graduated with Pfeiffer in
1965, has to get my vote, despite
the fine play of Geof Berlin over
the past three-years.

By MIKE PHILLIPS
Senior attackman Downy McCarty made his last Homewood
stick appearance his most outstanding Saturday, as his five goals
and one assist led the Hopkins lacrosse team to a 10-8 conquest of
previously-unbeaten Maryland,
thus clinching the school's first
undisputed collegiate championship since 1957.
The score was tied 8-8 midway
through the fourth period of that
topsy-turvy contest, witnessed by
as estimated 11,000 fans, when
McCarty's final two scores provided the Jay victory margin. The
6-1 senior put home a loose ball
from the side of the crease following a Phil Buck shot on extra-man
at 6:35 of the period, and came
from behind about two minutes
later for his fourth unassisted
score of the day.
Early Lead
McCarty's first two scores, both
unassisted, sparked Hopkins to a
2-0 lead by 6:00 of the second
quarter; in the early going the
Jays, with fine midfield play,
thoroughly dominated the action
and were only deterred from a bigger lead by the (to put it mildly)
outstanding work of Terp goalie
Norm Vander Schuyt. Hopkins had
an extra-man advantage at least
four times in the first period, and

Maryland got no more than five
shots in the opening fifteen minutes.
However, the College Park contingent staged the first of many
rallies from there, and knotted the
count at 3-3 by halftime. Middie
Steve Pfeiffer fed crease attackman Fred Graham for a fifteen
foot straightaway shot on extraman a minute after McCarty's
second goal, while Joe Cowan
made it 3-1 by coming from behind and putting an over-the-shoulder shot past Vander Schuyt at
8:00 of the period. Then Maryland midfielder Reed Kaestner(on
a high bounce shot) and attackman Doug Carter(on another feed
from Pfeiffer) tallied before the
half to induce the tie.
LaVaute Scores
Terp attackman Steve LaVaute
put his team ahead 4-3 three minutes into the second half, before
Hopkins ripped off three scores inside of a minute to move ahead
6-4. Cowan(on a feed from McCarty) scored from about ten feet to
the front and right of the goal on
extra-man at 5:50; tallied on a
similar play from the left after
Phil Kneip's assist thirty seconds
later; and fed McCarty in front of
the goal after the ensuing faceoff.
But Maryland came back again.
La Vaute and Kaestner scored
unassisted at 9:35 and 10:20 of

the period, before Jim Feely's ten
foot left-hander following Cowan's
feed from behind made it temporarily 7-6 a minute later. Then,
with a minute left in the quarter,
Pfeiffer and Graham teamed up for
an extra-man play like that which
scored in the second period, as the
Maryland crease attackman drilled
a low bouncer past Hopkins goalie
Geoff Berlin to make the score 7-7
after three periods.
Final Quarter Action
LaVaute put the Terps ahead
for the last time twenty-five seconds into the final period, when
he apparently surprised Berlin
with a medium-range, right-handed, on-the-run bounce shot; but
Buck fed Charlie Goodell thirty
seconds later to again knot the
count. From there, the action
went back and forth for about
eight minutes, setting the stage
for McCarty's late heroics.
As inferred above, the play of
the Hopkins midfields, matched
against Maryland units generally
rated the country's best, was a
major factor in the win. The Jays
were outdone 63-56 as a team on
ground balls; but, paced by soph
Doug Honig and senior Bob Carter, took fifteen of twenty-four
faceoffs, and outshot the Terps
62-31.The quality of performance
of the second (Carter, Wes Bachur,
and Bill Scroggs) and third (Feely,
Steve Latson, and Russ Moore)
midfields dropped little from that
of the first, where injured soph
Andy Fisher did a capable fill-in
for hobbled regular Charlie Coker.
Cowan Ties Record '
For all the fuss over teammate
McCarty, Cowan's customary pow
ers hardly declined against Maryland, as the 5-10 junior solidified
his claim to a second straight first
team All-America bid by recording three goals and two assists and
thus (with thirty scores and 45 assists) tieing the school socrirrg record of 75 points set by Billy Morrill in 1959. McCarty finished the
year with 51 points (31 and 20)
and crease attackman Kneip with
32(27 and 5).
All in all, in this writer's opinion, the 10-8 final margin for the
Maryland game was a bit deceptive, as Hopkins superiorities were
manifest in many areas.The abouteven midfield play aside, the
Homewood squad showed a marked advantage at both ends of the
field: the Jays bombarded Vander
Schuyt with 62 shots to the 31
Maryland sent at Berlin; few, if.
any, Terp scores were the result
of an attackman clearly beating
the close defense of Mike Clark,
John Cardillo, Paul Weiss, and
Joe Carlton; while Cowan and
McCarty often shook Maryland defenders Jack Dailey and Hugh
Mallon, and were only prevented
from scoring more prolifically by
Vander Schuyt's heroics. In fact,
if anything kept Maryland in the
game,especially in the early going,
it was the work of the 5-10 junior
Terp netminder, at least ten of
whose 24 saves were a spectacular
variety.
Saturday's game marked the final appearance for seniors McCarty Kneip, Bachur, Carter, Berlin,
Joe Carlton (who performed very
well — as a substitute close defenseman in the fourth quarter),
Doug Tribull, and Ted Leach.
